I believe that honourable senators and the public generally should look at the very serious studies that have been undertaken on the advantageous and beneficial effects on the economy that the migration policy has had at each stage of its development since the last world war. There have been a number of studies. I will not refer to them here. No doubt honourable senators will have seen them. However, it is evident from those studies that, rather than being a disadvantage in relation to employment, and increased migration policy, a policy which is realistic and involves large numbers of persons coming into this country is a very important factor in providing employment opportunities for Australia.

We are allowed only five minutes to speak on this very important paper, and I note that Senator Martin will adjourn debate on it. I turn to the question of family reunion, which was raised by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney . I notice that the family reunion intake is expected to reach 42,000 in 1984-85 , compared with a mid-range of 37,000 in 1983-84. The paper states:

The Orderly Departure Program from Vietnam, which is family reunion, is expected to expand from 2,000 in 1983-84 to 5,000 in 1984-85. A further 2,000 places are allowed for expected expansion from sources other than Vietnam.

I agree with what the Leader of the Opposition has said. Most of us no doubt have encountered very pitiful examples here of mothers with children whose fathers are in Vietnam. Since my time is running out, I endorse the comments made by the Leader of the Opposition. I have one glaring example of that problem , stretching over a period of some years. I hope that the Government can take administrative action to speed up the process for these long awaited family reunions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking briefly to the 1984-85 immigration program, as the previous speaker has said, it appears that in 1984- 85 there will be a fall back in numbers. Whereas in the previous year it appears that 86,000 visas were issued, this year the number will be something less-in the vicinity of some 62,000 to 64,000. I have always thought that when considering the intake figures we should also consider the figures of people who have left Australia. There is always quite a number of people who leave, which at times is surprising to me. In order to establish the actual figure of increased migration, we should also have the figures of those who have left.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the overall situation, it appears to me that we will see a boost, as has been reported, in the European skilled migrant intake. Those migrants will be from the technical area and will include those who want to be involved in, for example, business and investment. They are certainly to be encouraged. I am also pleased, like other speakers, to see that people will continue to come to Australia from Vietnam and South East Asia under the family reunion program because I believe that we have a responsibility not only in the area of refugees but also in regard to those people who want to come here from South East Asia for family reunions. As I see it, Australia is part of South East Asia and has a responsibility to the people of that area. Our future lies very much with the people to our north and in the ensuing years it will pay Australia well to become more associated with and be more understanding of our neighbours and, when necessary and possible, to have those people come and live with us.

We have come a long way over the last few years in our immigration policies. People have come to join us in this country from, I think, as many as 72 or 74 nations. They have brought much to Australia. So, like other speakers, I hope that our immigration numbers do not dwindle and that we look to further the immigration of people from all those areas, such as England, Europe and South East Asia, who can give much to Australia.

A lot has been said about immigration policies and some of the debate over the last few weeks has been rather emotional. I will say no more about that at the moment. All I wish to say now is that we should confine ourselves to the very sound principles of immigration set down by Mr Michael MacKellar, when he was Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, in the House of Representatives on 7 June 1978. He laid down nine principles, saying:
These nine principles have a common basis: The interests of Australia and its people, together with compassion and international responsibility.
I seek leave to have these principles incorporated in Hansard. The document has been shown to the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, and to the Government Whip.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
MINISTERIAL STATEMENT BY MR MacKELLAR (WARRINGAH-MINISTER FOR IMMIGRATION AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS)
Immigration Policies and Australia's Population
Immigration Principles

1. It is fundamental to national sovereignty that the Australian Government alone should determine who will be admitted to Australia. No person other than an Australian citizen, or a constituent member of the Australian community, has a basic right to enter Australia.

2. Apart from people admitted as refugees and for family reunion, migrant entry criteria should be developed on the basis of benefit to the Australian community , and the social, economic and related requirements within Australia. As a general rule, Australia will not admit for settlement people who would represent an economic burden to Australia through inordinate claims on welfare, health or other resources, who would endanger the community by criminal or other anti- social activities, or whose entry would be to their own detriment.
3. The size and composition of migrant intakes should not jeopardise social cohesiveness and harmony within the Australian community.

4. Immigration policy should be applied on a basis which is non-discriminatory. There are external restraints on the extent to which Australia can apply a non- discriminatory policy. Some countries will not allow their nationals to emigrate ; other countries allow only those with exit permits to leave; some countries will not permit the emigration of skilled and professional workers. Some countries will not allow advertising for migration purposes, others will not allow immigration offices to be established within their territories, or allow immigration officers to operate within their territories. In addition, there are varying degrees of interest in migration to Australia in particular areas. The principle of non-discrimination means that policy will be applied consistently to all applicants regardless of their race, colour, nationality, descent, national or ethnic origin or sex.

5. Applicants should be considered for migration as individuals or individual family units, not as community groups. An exception will be refugees in designated refugee situations, although even in such circumstances the criteria for selection will be related to the characteristics of individual applicants.

6. Eligibility and suitability standards for migrants should reflect Australian social mores and Australian law. Polygamous unions will not be accepted, or the entry of child fiances. The concept of immediate family, for eligibility purposes, will be derived from the Australian norm, that is, the unit consisting of husband, wife and minor unmarried children.

7. Migration to Australia should be for permanent settlement although there should be no barrier preventing the departure of persons wishing to leave. The guest-worker migration flow until recently popular in the industrialised countries of Western Europe will not be adopted for Australia.

8. While migrants will have the same rights as other Australian residents to choose their place of residence individually or collectively, enclave settlement will not be encouraged. Immigration policy will not consider communities for mass movement to Australia in situations where enclave settlement would occur.

9. Policies governing entry and settlement should be based on the premise that immigrants should integrate into Australian society. Migrants will be given every opportunity, consistent with this premise, to preserve and disseminate their ethnic heritage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

This statement accompanies the tabling of instruments which establish guidelines under legislation which was recently passed by this Parliament, the Liquid Fuel Emergency Act 1984. Honourable senators will remember that the legislation provided a framework for the administration of a system of allocation of fuel in the event that there was a liquid fuel emergency caused by difficulties either in Australia or overseas. The Opposition agrees with the statement made by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, that recent events in the Middle East are a reminder of the sorts of circumstances which have the potential to give rise to difficulties here in Australia.

The legislation passed by the Senate is not simple. It provides for a quite complex set of arrangements which give the Commonwealth Government very considerable powers in the event of an emergency. The full detail, however, is not contained in the legislation. The guidelines tabled today provide the detailed mechanism which would apply if a liquid fuel emergency actually arose. The legislation provides that those guidelines are subject to disallowance by this Parliament and we have the normal period for consideration of those guidelines-I think some 15 sitting days. It is worth remembering that the original legislation was substantially amended in the Senate following very detailed discussions on the legislation between the Government and industry and between the Government and the Opposition. I acknowledged at that time the fact that the Minister was prepared to look at the very real difficulties which arose under the legislation as it was originally introduced and the amendments which were made did provide the Government with a much more workable framework for a possible emergency. I wish to reserve my position and the position of the Opposition on the details contained in the instruments tabled today.

I note with regret the Minister's statement that it has not proved possible to simplify the language in the guidelines as the Minister and others would have wished. I did at the time the legislation was being debated ask the Minister whether some attempt could be made to simplify what was proposed because it is complex to the point where those who have to use the regulations or the instruments in a practical sense will have some difficulty. I note with, I suppose what I would call second rate satisfaction, the fact that the Minister has acknowledged the difficulty and has directed his Department to prepare a plain language guide to the Act and to the guidelines in order that they may be more readily understood in the community. It is a sad thing that we have reached the stage that the laws passed by this Parliament and the subordinate legislation which is made under those laws is so complex that it is incapable of being understood by those who have to rely on it and who have to use it and we have to turn to plain man's guides. I say that not in any adversary or divisive sense; it is a real problem. A great deal of Commonwealth legislation is almost beyond the wit of the expert to understand, let alone the inexpert whom it also governs.

I simply say to the Senate that we should all be conscious of this problem and those honourable senators such as Senator Tate opposite who have some role in perusing legislation in a formal sense through the Senate's committee arrangements, and indeed all of us, should be concerned to try to produce the simplest legislative guides possible to the community. So I give the Government notice that we will carefully examine the guidelines which have been laid down by Senator Walsh this afternoon. Of course we will, as not doubt he has, consult carefully with industry to try to ensure that there is a practical working system on which the people of Australia can rely should we have the misfortune to have a liquid fuel emergency, and we will do our best to ensure that the Opposition makes a positive contribution to ensuring that we are not damaged unnecessarily should such an emergency arise. As it appears that no one else wishes to speak, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
(Quorum formed)

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS (PROHIBITION OF IMPORTATION OF NUCLEAR HARDWARE) BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 April, on motion by Senator Chipp:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jessop will be the main speaker for the Opposition in the debate on the Customs (Prohibition of Importation of Nuclear Hardware) Bill 1984. I just want to make a couple of preliminary remarks. I understand that a speaker from the Government side will speak very shortly. This Bill represents a part of a Bill which was previously brought before the Senate by Senator Chipp. I believe that he performs something of a service in bringing the Bill before the Senate, even though I have a fundamental disagreement with him with respect to what he proposes.

SPEECH.PARA: In very broad terms, the Bill would impose a general prohibition on the importation of nuclear hardware with some exceptions being permitted for medical and industrial purposes. I will leave the detailing of those exceptions to Senator Jessop and, I hope, in due course to a Government Minister if one appears. The concern of the Opposition in this matter is that we are totally at odds with Senator Chipp on the principle. Indeed, the Senate will have some further opportunity to debate this principle when the statement on the Slatyer committee of inquiry is tabled in the Senate later this afternoon. There really is a fundamental difference between us. That difference lies in the Opposition's belief that it is in the interests of Australia and the world that we should advance the peaceful use of nuclear energy at the same time as we should play a very active part in ensuring that the negative side of nuclear possibilities, the possibility of nuclear war, is fought against as substantially as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your problem is that you cannot separate them.

—In a sense the difference which lies between some of us is encapsulated in the interjection of Senator Georges who says that the two things cannot be separated. That is a view which I am sure he holds very dearly, although I am not sure it is a view he will necessarily vote to support. The Prime Minister of Australia, the Hon. Bob Hawke, expressed the precisely contrary view in an address to the University of Western Australia just before Easter. I do not have that address with me at the moment but I will quote from it in the course of debate later this afternoon. The Opposition's view is clear and is gaining more and more support as more people in the community are prepared to take the time to examine the detailed arguments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill provides a service insofar as it focuses attention on a genuine difference of opinion which exists in the Australian community but it represents a minority view and a view which in fact is very wrong. It is not for me to make out the full case. That will be done on behalf of the Opposition by Senator Jessop. I will resume my seat shortly and let him get at it. In any event, whilst Senator Chipp has refined his proposition and has opened up some exceptions to the original total prohibition he proposed and those exceptions relate to some aspects of the peaceful use of nuclear energy, it is the clear view of the Opposition that the exceptions he has permitted are not wide enough. They do not cover many of the acceptable and proper uses of nuclear energy at present in this community. For that reason alone the Bill is impractical.

In any event, it is wrong to take the totally negative approach which is being adopted by Senator Chipp in this Bill. Whilst it is possible to admire the strength with which he holds and propounds the view, the Opposition takes the stance that he is wrong and it is becoming increasingly confident that the Government, which has had a rather divided view on these matters, is moving to a view which has much more in common with that of the Opposition. We have yet to see the Prime Minister's statement which, I think, is being put down in the House of Representatives about now, but when we debate that later in the afternoon I think there will be cause for some pleasure in the fact that there is some coming together of views on these matters, with the Government moving steadily in the direction which has been advocated by the Opposition in recent years. I speak to indicate the Opposition's attitude to this Bill, but I leave the more detailed arguments to my colleague, Senator Jessop. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend simply to make some remarks for a few minutes before the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, enters the debate, as did the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney. The Australian Democrats, in the person of Senator Chipp, brought into the Senate this Bill for an Act to prohibit the importation of nuclear hardware and for purposes connected there with. I think it has to be recognised that this Bill represents a very considerable advance in the attitude of the Australian Democrats to the uses to which a community may put this remarkable element, uranium. The fact is that in October of last year a private member's Bill was introduced into this chamber by the Democrats. As I recall, that Bill dealt with an absolute prohibition on the export of uranium and yellowcake and on the importation of nuclear hardware. It was pointed out in the course of debate that this would have a very detrimental and drastic effect on the operations of the nuclear reactor research establishment at Lucas Heights which plays a very important role, among other things, in the provision of medical isotopes. I think it was conceded by the Democrats that there would have to be some modification of their absolute prohibition of the importation of nuclear hardware if the Australian Atomic Energy Commission were to continue to provide that service to those suffering from various diseases in Australia, principally cancer, who are dependent upon the production of those medical isotopes.

SPEECH.PARA: I see that in the Bill the Democrats envisage that permission be granted by the Minister for Resources and Energy to import nuclear hardware if he is satisfied that the hardware is essential for the purpose of enabling the Australian Atomic Energy Commission to maintain its capacity to produce isotopes for medical or industrial use. I think that it is important both philosophically and ideologically and also represents a real breakthrough that there has been an admission by the Australian Democrats that this element can have uses which are beneficial for mankind, if the community is prepared to put the most stringent safeguards on the use of this resource and direct use of that resource to matters which are truly beneficial to mankind. Whilst they are not yet prepared to go so far as to say that the production of electrical energy for peaceful purposes and perhaps commercial profit is such a beneficial use of this material , nevertheless their concession that medical isotopes are such is, I think, a very important breakthrough. I believe we ought to congratulate the Democrats on their openness to that possibility. The Democrats talk not only about medical isotopes but also industrial isotopes. That is another important use of isotopes .

It strikes me that the definition is still a little narrow in that we know that isotopes are also used for agricultural reasons, for hydrology and in various environmental studies. These uses are extremely important. Its use in hydrology is particularly important as it traces the movement of underground water systems in Australia. This is extremely crucial to our understanding of that water resource which is so essential to the development of our agriculture and the production of wealth and employment in this country. What is disappointing about this definition is that it would not allow, if it were implemented, the Atomic Energy Commission to carry out research into the properties of substances such as synroc. It does not seem to envisage-I do not know whether Senator Chipp intended this-the Australian Atomic Energy Commission playing any part in the important role of trying to find out how we can entrap nuclear wastes and ensure that they are held in form over future generations which provides no risk, or as little risk as is scientifically and humanly possible to achieve, in the irradiation of persons or substances coming into contact with leached or escaping nuclear materials. It seems to me that the least one could expect of the Commission would be that it engage in the world-wide search for a surer means of dealing with radioactive wastes. It seems to me that that ought to be part of any scheme which allowed the Commission, under very stringent safeguards , to remain in operation at Lucas Heights in order to carry out certain experiments.

I note that the Democrats' Bill provides for a very elaborate system of laying before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of a declaration by the Minister of a granting of permission to import certain hardware. I believe that would be a useful technique for the community, not merely Ministers or parliamentarians who are members of special committees, to keep an eye on things . The public exposure of permissions granted can be well appreciated in a situation in which the public needs its confidence built up as to the adequacy, stringency and purposes for which the Atomic Energy Commission is able to carry out certain experiments and the production of certain isotopes. Briefly, I believe this Bill is a very considerable advance in the Democrats' thinking. I believe it is to be welcomed for that reason. I think that the Bill is still somewhat narrow. As I say, it does not allow the Atomic Energy Commission, as I read it, to deal with research into the disposal of nuclear wastes. For that reason, I am unable to support the Bill at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to a point of order. The Opposition, in an attempt to be co-operative, has-
—That is not a point of order.

—The failure of the Government to have a Minister in this place to deal with the Bill is inexcusable. The discourtesy of the Attorney-General, who is at the table now, is typical. I merely wish to say that the Opposition has tried to co-operate to prevent the Government making a fool of itself. The Government has an obligation to respond to the Bill. We have had the courtesy from Senator Tate of trying to provide some filler while the Minister for Resources and Energy collects his thoughts. It is the normal procedure in this place for the Government to put its views on a private member's Bill and the Opposition awaits that privilege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not plead guilty to all the charges laid by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, but I did have one or two pressing matters to attend to this afternoon and I apologise for not being in the Senate at the ideal time. If Senator Chaney wants to know the Government's response to the Customs ( Prohibition of Importation of Nuclear Hardware) Bill, it is, as Senator Tate has indicated, that we cannot accept it. There has been a Government decision not to support the Bill. It is an updated and improved version of the Bill which the Australian Democrats introduced last year and which sought to prohibit the importation of the materials necessary to continue the research and other work which is conducted at Lucas Hieghts; whereas this Bill provides exceptions which allow ministerial approval for materials necessary to maintain the Lucas Heights establishment, provided those materials are used solely for the production of medical or industrial isotopes.

SPEECH.PARA: It appears to me that the Democrats are not aware of the impossibility of operating either HIFAR or MOATA reactors exclusively for that purpose. If the reactor is active at all it will produce products other than those which are of an industrial or medical nature only. For example, I am advised that the HIFAR reactor is involved in the production of isotopes for sedimentation studies-that is, studies on the movement of sand in estuaries and near shore areas. The reactor is involved also in environmental studies-for example, the movement of heavy metals in the Northern Territory uranium mining areas-and flow studies of gases and liquids in pipes, ponds and termite tracing.

Neutron beam facilities provide an important research tool for the study of the structure of materials, including semi-conductors, biological membranes, metal alloys and a wide range of chemicals. I am advised that at present all of HIFAR' s horizontal neutron beam facilities are in use by universities. That work is being co-ordinated through the Australian Institute of Nuclear Science and Engineering. In addition, a wide range of materials are irradiated in the HIFAR reactor for a number of different purposes. Such materials include samples of synroc, which as Senator Tate indicated are irradiated in support of the development of the material as a medium for the long term disposal of radioactive waste. I would be surprised if that was a line of inquiry or research work which the Democrats would want to stop.

The Atomic Energy Commission has initiated a commercial activity based on the irradiation of silicon for application in electrical and electronic industries. The operation of the reactor also has some importance in the safeguards and research and development area. Several projects within Australia's proposed support program to International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards are based on the use of HIFAR-for example, to safeguard approaches for irradiated spent fuel storage ponds and the burning and cooling time measurements of fuel elements.

In practice, HIFAR is used to produce radio isotopes for medical and industrial purposes on a continuous basis while it is at power. It is not technical feasible to isolate from the other aspects the medical and industrial aspects or components of HIFAR's output. Therefore, the advice that I have received is that the practical effect-I know it is not the intended effect-of the Democrats' Bill would be to close down the HIFAR reactor.

Similar considerations apply to the smaller MOATA reactor, which is currently used to analyse minerals and ores, using neutron activation analysis, neutron radiography of industrial components and plants, as well as facilitating research on neutron beams for cancer therapy and limited radio isotope production when HIFAR is shut down. It seems to me-and I think it has probably occurred to Senator Chipp too-that some of those activities could be classified as industrial or medical. They are related to industrial or medical but the terms in which the Bill is written are so restrictive, we believe, that the practical effect of the Bill, if it were to become an Act, would be to suspend the operation of both the HIFAR and the MOATA reactors.

Again, I know this is not the intention of the Bill, but I think it is worth making the point that the operation of a nuclear facility in Australia for medical, industrial, agricultural or pure research purposes is significant in that it enables Australia to supply nuclear technology to countries which do not have any indigenous nuclear facilities. It is a well established view inside and outside the International Atomic Energy Agency that that sort of technical assistance for countries which do not have any nuclear facilities could be used as a lever, if you like, or an incentive for those countries to abide by more strictly or to continue to abide by the effective international control of nuclear energy and of all nuclear activity. In other words, it is an incentive which we can offer other countries which would make more effective the international agreements and rules governing nuclear technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the United States of America been able to use that leverage to stop Pakistan or India making a bomb?

—The advice I have is that Pakistan is not in that position. It is believed, indeed I think it is well established, that the Indians have made a nuclear explosive device-I am not sure how efficient it is as a bomb-and that steps have been taken to see that that could not be repeated. I thought that most of the materials supplied to India came from Canada and not the United States. Anyway, I do not think that is a valid analogy to what I am saying. I am not suggesting that Australia would be supplying reactors to other countries; I am suggesting that we would be supplying to other countries the completely benign products which come out of nuclear establishments.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not really think there is much more that I can say. I acknowledge that the underlying intentions of this Bill are benign, but its effects would be far more wide-ranging than I believe the Australian Democrats realise. If it were passed it effectively would close down the Lucas Heights establishment. This would not only deprive Australia of access to benign nuclear research on the products of nuclear facilities which have application in industry and in medicine; it would also prevent Australia from being in a position to be a supplier of those benign products to, generally, smaller countries in our region, although they would not necessarily have to be smaller countries. Finally, the Atomic Energy Commission is a significant employer. The total number of staff at Lucas Heights is of the order of 1,200. I am sure that Senator Mason, at least, would not like to see an employer of that significance having to close down and dismiss all those employees. I guess that Senator Mason has an appreciation of and indeed a direct interest in the maintenance of employment in his electorate of New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney has indicated that the Opposition will not support the Customs (Prohibition of Importation of Nuclear Hardware) Bill, and this is for very good reasons. I agree with Senator Walsh that, although the Bill provides for importation of materials that will assist in the manufacture of medical isotopes, it has some tremendous deficiencies. Essentially, the Bill is aimed at prohibiting the importation of, firstly, enrichment equipment; secondly, reactor components, including fuel rods and, thirdly, spent fuel rods, unless these are to be used solely by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission in the production of medical or industrial isotopes. Unfortunately, as Senator Walsh has pointed out, the operations of the Atomic Energy Commission with respect to the HIFAR reactor go a lot further than merely producing medical isotopes. It produces isotopes for other purposes, for example , for agriculture and hydrology, and for scientific research by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission and universities.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh mentioned Synroc research, which is a very significant part of the activity of the AAEC, developing the technology that has been initiated by Professor Ringwood of the Australian National University. This will contribute quite a lot to safety in relation to highly radioactive storage technology. I know that the many countries that have nuclear power stations operating at present are concerned that maximum safety standards are explored in the storage of highly radioactive waste, and they are giving very careful consideration to including the Synroc process in this context. This could mean a lot to Australia so far as export income is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Technology transfers.

—Exactly so. Unfortunately in the past Australia has failed to recognise that it is a world leader in many research initiatives, and the synroc process is a classic example of that. The efforts that are being employed by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, in developing this process to an industrial stage, will mean a lot to Australia in the future in selling this technology, transferring it to other countries.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other aspects of the HIFAR reactor's operations that would be inhibited if this Bill were passed. The Commission is engaged in non-destructive testing, in semiconductor and radiation physics, forensic studies, nuclear safeguards research and development, and fusion studies, which is a most significant aspect of its activities. I think the Australian Democrats fail to recognise that HIFAR is designed for continuous operation and it would not be practicable to operate it in the way apparently envisaged in this Bill. It could not be shut down when not irradiating targets for medical or industrial isotopes and restarted when again required for that purpose. Thus the Bill would again have the effect of leading to the closure of the HIFAR operation. To all intents and purposes this is Australia's only indigenous source of radio isotopes.

The Bill would also lead to the closure of the other reactor, the MOATA, which is not used for isotopic production and hence, under the Bill, could not be refuelled. The uses of this reactor include the analysis of ores, wastes, radiography of plants and industrial samples, and archaeological dating. A lot of very interesting work has been done by the Atomic Energy Commission with respect to the historical origin of much of our ground waters. In fact, some time ago I visited Lucas Heights and was impressed by the carbon dating procedures they were carrying out, which indicated, for example, that the ground waters in the Simpson Desert area dated back something like 500,000 years. That does not sound very important, but I regard water resources as being fundamental to Australia's future.

The proposed restrictions on imports of equipment suitable for uranium enrichment could affect the project on the safeguarding of research and development scale centrifuge enrichment plants being undertaken by the Atomic Energy Commission and the Australian Safeguards Office on behalf of the International Atomic Energy Agency. The restriction could also affect the extension of enrichment technology to other areas which are now under examination, including the separation of isotopes for waste treatment purposes. The definition of nuclear hardware used in the Bill could apply to analytical instruments such as mass spectrometers and to apparatus such as fusion vessels and particle accelerators. Restrictions of this nature would have a much wider impact than just on the Atomic Energy Commission as such instruments and apparatus are used by a number of other institutions in Australia.

I respect the motivation of the Democrats. Senator Chipp is obviously sincere in believing he is going to do some good by stopping the nuclear industry in Australia. He believes, I think quite genuinely, that preventing our materials going overseas and preventing nuclear hardware materials from coming to Australia will have a miraculous effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Well, it seems to me that the honourable senator does. Whenever we mention the question of nuclear weapons, we all support disarmament. There is no question about that. Then we find that the Flat Earth people on the opposite side-when I refer to the Flat Earth people I mean the socialist Left of the Australian Labor Party-suddenly start confusing two issues, nuclear weapons and the generation of electricity through nuclear power stations. They are two separate issues as far as I am concerned and as far as the people who have bothered to study the whole problem are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment there are very serious diplomatic consultations going on in the world with respect to nuclear disarmament. There is only one way this will be achieved and that is through very intense and careful diplomatic discussion. I was talking to a European ambassador only the other day, and he agreed with a statement that was offered to me by an expert from our Department of Foreign Affairs who has dealt with the non-proliferation matter over a number of years. They agree that the only way to stop nuclear armament is for the two super- powers to de-escalate their armaments. At that time, if both the super-powers de -escalate their armaments and start reducing their capacity in that area, we will be able to get on side the British, the Red Chinese-the mainland Chinese who are also involved in this area-and the French. At that stage we might be able to see a real result in the matters that concern us all. The nuclear power industry is an entirely different proposition. As we all know, if we have read the agreements with countries to which we provide uranium for their own use, we will find very stringent provisions laid down. For example, last year Senator Mason told us what we are told by members of the Caldicott family, who occasionally come out here to give us the benefit of their enlightened knowledge . They inform us through the media that our Australian uranium, which is used to generate power in Finland, finds its way to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and is reprocessed for the extraction of plutonium.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that make you feel proud?

—That demonstrates the total ignorance of Senator Chipp and his colleagues. I have been trying to be kind to Senator Chipp but he makes it very difficult when he starts talking a lot of nonsense. I do not know whether Senator Chipp has read the agreement between Australia and Finland; I dare to suggest that he has not for, if he had, he would know that article 7 of the agreement provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Nuclear material subject to this agreement shall be
(a) transfer beyond the jurisdiction of the recipient Party,
(b) enriched to more than 20 percent in the isotope. U235, or
(c) reprocessed,
only with the prior written consent of the supplier Party,

TALK.START.PARA: —You believe that rubbish, do you?

—I might be naive but I have yet to learn from anyone in authority or with knowledge, as Senator Chipp purports to have, that any transfer of material has taken place between Finland and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. I should like the honourable senator to produce some evidence to enlighten me if the situation is otherwise.
—How many nuclear bombs were not made from uranium? There are 50, 000 of them in the world now.
—If I were Senator Chipp, I would be more worried about other things at the moment.
—The fate of the world is not important!
—Order! Senator Jessop, you will address your remarks to the Chair.

—Certainly, Mr Acting Deputy President, I become distracted occasionally. I have already stated there would not be one person in this Parliament, and probably in Australia, who would not support that view on nuclear disarmament. There are other things that I would be worried about. What about laser weapons that are currently being explored, developed and exploited? They present an incredible threat to the community of the world.
—Especially when it is added to the other threat.
—Without being distracted further, I suggest that people ought to examine the subject in a scientific and engineering way, if that is possible.
—Also a moral way.

—I hold the view that Australia has an obligation to provide its abundant natural resources to the rest of the world, for many countries have no resources of their own. I am one who believes that is a very important moral responsibility of Australia. It concerns me that Australia should be divided on this matter. I like to think that the Labor Party is gradually coming round to the idea that the nuclear fuel cycle will present tremendous benefits to Australia. It is the most satisfactory environmental energy source as far as I am concerned-far more suitable than coal-fired power stations. For example, problems are being experienced in Germany. I have read that 80 per cent of its forests are dying simply because of acid rain produced by coal-fired power stations. We need to have another look at the question of producing power in the conventional way.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently I noticed a reference by Senator Chipp to several other alternative energy sources, in a letter to the editor of the Australian Financial Review. But he stated little in that letter about what the alternatives were. I tried to appreciate what he was getting at and replied in this way; that it has been estimated that all the alternative energy sources available in Britain-which include hydro power, tidal power, wave power, wind power, solar power, geothermal power and refuse conversion-would contribute an upper limit of only 15 per cent of that country's total electricity requirements by the turn of the century.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your source for that?
—My source happens to be the Uranium Information Centre.
—Ha, ha!

—That has been checked by researchers from outside that organisation, from universities. I do not believe any one source. I checked in several ways to make sure that that is correct. That would be substantiated also by authorities in the United Kingdom, if Senator Chipp cares to take the trouble to check it. I repeat that all those alternative forms of energy would provide a maximum of 15 per cent of Britain's total electricity requirements by the turn of the century. Those alternatives would still not be able to be substituted for base load power generation required 24 hours a day. It cannot seriously be suggested that the current listed alternative energy sources would be able to replace nuclear and coal-fired power stations.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chipp talked about alternative technology having many environmental effects. But Austria is currently planning to build 50 hydro-electricity projects by 1997, to cope with an anticipated 3.2 to 3.6 per cent annual increase in electricity demand. Of course environmentalists will be protesting about that because that will require the construction of more than 23 new dams. I guess the next thing we know we will be dealing with that problem. Australia must develop its nuclear industry in a peaceful way. We also should not exclude construction of a nuclear power station in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about a bomb? Do you think we should make a bomb?
—No, I do not think we want any bombs. I am not suggesting we make bombs. That is the immediate and emotive reaction we have come to expect from Senator Chipp.
—If Indonesia got a bomb, would you advocate our making one?

—I am a peaceful person. I would not advocate that. I believe non -proliferation is the way to go, and that is what I support. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard some letters to editors of various newspapers. They will reinforce what I have had to say.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
Australian Financial Review
10 April 1984
Economically anti-uranium

Sir, Your editorial on uranium (AFR, 29/3/84), like many you have written on this topic, conveys the impression that all opponents of uranium mining propagate inchoate fears, horror stories and twilight fantasies.
This is not the case. Many people who oppose uranium mining have exceptionally valid economic arguments, that the proponents of the nuclear fuel cycle choose to ignore or distort.
Consider the following:

When all facets of a nuclear reactor are included in the cost estimates, nuclear generated electricity is costing $9,000 per kilowatt delivered. That means it is costing a power utility $90,000 to provide the electricity required to heat a house; more than the cost of the entire house itself.

January, 1984 brought three announcements of nuclear reactors being cancelled in the US. With costs as above, that is not surprising. When the US Energy Information Administration surveyed 47 reactors in January it found 36 cost at least twice as much as originally projected, and 13 of these cost four times as much.
According to the Energy Information administration, renewable energy resources- mainly solar and wind-provide twice as much delivered energy as nuclear power.

Renewable energy resources are the fastest growing sector despite the government disincentives they have overcome, and despite the government incentives offered to the least efficient energy technologies such as nuclear power.

Despite government's distortion of the market, consumer choice is clearly opting for the cheaper, more efficient renewable energy technologies. These technologies are not a pipedream of the future. They are available and being chosen by consumers now.
Pro-nuclear advocates who also claim to be advocates of market forces should recognise that the market is clearly advocating renewable technologies above all else.
These are crucial issues, in addition to the non-proliferation question, for Australia.
We cannot export a commodity that supports a totally inefficient, uneconomical and dangerous industry.
DON CHIPP Leader of the Australian Democrats
Australian Financial Review
17 April 1984
Economics of nuclear power

Sir, It is interesting to note that senator Chipp, in another attack on domestic nuclear power (AFR, 10/4/84), has refrained from resorting to the much used emotive argument that civil nuclear power programs lead to the proliferation of nuclear weapons.
Perhaps he has discovered the existence of abundant evidence against this argument.
The Democrats are now declaring that electricity generated by nuclear power stations is uneconomic when all facets are included in the cost estimates.
This is incorrect and to persist with this view is deceptive.
All power stations, whether they be nuclear or conventional, include in the estimated cost of electricity generation such factors as the grid loss and the operational ''down-time'' of the plant.
Extra cost facets of nuclear power facilities cover their financial and technical responsibility for the waste they generate and the de-commissioning of the plant.
These companies do not foolishly absorb these costs only to pay them out later when the power station ceases to operate.
Rather, they are all included in the total cost of power production and are passed on to the community.
Yet, with all these costs included, 31 countries have decided to turn to nuclear power because it is economical and cost-competitive.

Scotland is one example. There nuclear power accounted for 38.8 per cent of all electricity generated in 1982-83, and the cost of nuclear electricity was 2.21p/ kWh as compared with 2.92p/kWh for coal and oil-fired stations.

It is unfortunate that the Democrats base their anti-uranium mining campaign on highly selective information peculiar to a limited number of reactors overseas, some of which have not yet been completed, when the vast majority of the 306 nuclear power stations currently operating have been producing, and will continue to produce, cheap, essential electricity for millions of the world's people.
D. S. JESSOP, Senator for South Australia, Parliament House, Canberra.
Australian Financial Review
Nuclear power economics

Sir: Congratulations to Senator Jessop (AFR, April 17) for scolding Senator Chipp (AFR, April 10) about his distortions concerning nuclear power economics. I admit to skyhigh construction costs for selected US reactors not yet completed , and to cancellations which really were rooted in the recession and resultant drop in demand for electricity, but we must not let Senator Chipp's other distortions blind us to the tremendous benefits accruing to electricity users in large areas of the US.

Those fortunate enough to live in an area served by pioneering nuclear utilities have fared very well. For example, in 1981 and 1982, the Commonwealth Edison Co of Chicago, Illinois, generated about 26 trillion kWh of electricity from nuclear reactors. Uranium was the source of 45 per cent of all the power Commonwealth Edison Co produced in those years.

The most cost savings due to nuclear generation over that which would have occurred if the same energy had been generated from low sulphur coal amounted to an average of about $600 million in both years, and over $2 billion compared with oil.

To put a ''bottom line'' aspect to these numbers, the 10-year savings on the Commonwealth Edison system due to nuclear generation as compared to the use of low-sulphur coal (with which Commonwealth has extensive experience) are over $3 billion, which is equivalent to almost three times the current investment Edison has in the plants installed in the early 1970s.

Solar and wind power have their place. Solar, especially, will grow in Australia where the latitude and climate favour its use, but a technological breakthrough is needed for solar electricity generation and for its storage for use at any time.

As for wind, I suggest you let any engineer make the numbers and one sees quickly it is all right for the outback but not for large scale power generation . It all boils down to the fact that for future electric power needs, the world must depend on nuclear and coal power generation.
RALPH W. DEUSTER, Senior Vice-president, Getty Oil Development Company Ltd, Minerals Division, North Sydney.
Australian Financial Review
Nuclear power and efficiency
Sir: Mr Sorentino's letter (AFR, May 3) displays the expected one-track thinking favoured by a number of pro-nuclear advocates.
We are proud to have been assisted in our work by Mr Amory Lovins. Mr Lovins is a distinguished academic who has advised US Presidents and many government leaders worldwide on energy policy.
He is at the forefront of a revolutionary approach to energy policy, the ''soft -path'' strategy.
Mr Lovins's advice is so well regarded that many US power utilities are hiring him to get them out of nuclear power.

The ''soft-path'' strategy has made clear that any new centralised electricity generating plant is uneconomic in the face of energy efficiency improvements and renewable resources. Nuclear power is just the most uneconomic source out of many uneconomic sources.

Indeed, many coal plants have been cancelled and since 1981, in the US, no new ones have been ordered. I acknowledge and welcome that. The reason is simple: the market is favouring the alternative technologies I describe over the centralised sources of coal or nuclear power.

The growth in nuclear power that is cited in favour of the industry in misleading. Reactors are under construction at the moment, not because of recent policy decisions, but because of delays and overruns caused by the inefficiencies of the technology.
They are the results of decisions taken in the mid-1970s when the alternative technologies were in a formative stage.
The best energy saving devices have come on to the market in the last two years , and thus have not been able to have an impact on reactors under construction.

The economic arguments-which have so many environmental and non-proliferation benefits as well-do not produce the coal versus nuclear conflict that Mr Sorentino concentrates on but rather the centralised sources versus efficiency improvements and renewable resources I have described.
DON CHIPP, Leader, Australian Democrats, Parliament House, Canberra.
Australian Financial Review
No nuclear conspiracy
Sir, Senator Jessop (AFR, April 17) is correct and Dr Mark Diesendorf (AFR, May 1) and Senator Don Chipp (AFR, May 17) are wrong regarding the cost competitiveness of base load nuclear power plant.

I consider Diesendorf's letter a devious exercise in irrelevance and another demonstration of the extravagant rhetoric of the seasoned anti-nuclear campaigner. It is beginning to wear thin on thinking Australians.

Ignoring the red herrings of ''US Government subsidies, wind power, the Reagan Administration, weapons to be used against striking coalminers, plutonium, etc'' this letter is a montage of out-of-context snippets by one who, apparently, has never done his homework on nuclear energy costing.

Irrefutable facts, based on the cold, hard free market economics of industrialised countries with nuclear power programs-even those rich in other fuels-show that nuclear energy costs based on capital construction of plant and fuel cycle costs (including research and development and plant decommissioning) are substantially less than that for coal and petroleum.

Does Diesendorf seriously challenge the audited, governmentally approved annual statistical reports of the relevant statutory authorities of France, Japan, Canada, Sweden, Finland, Switzerland, Belgium, West Germany, the Soviet Union, Spain and many others?

With regard to the US, Diesendorf conveniently neglects the reality that each State and each utility has to be considered separately. The fortunate States which had developed their power systems before the advent of ''uranium neurosis' ' have an enormous advantage in terms of the cost of nuclear electricity. They are the envy of those members of the American community caught up in the costly concomitants of successful plant construction delays inspired by the anti- nuclear lobby.

Any form of cost accounting can be challenged but, in Britain, the historical cost accounting of the Central Electricity Generating Board has been uniformly applied to coal, oil and nuclear plant and has shown a significant advantage for the last option. The innuendo of the word ''misleading'' hides the reality that all forms of accounting demonstrate the cost-effectiveness of Britain's magnox stations.

In regard to British advanced gas-cooled reactors or possible pressurised water reactors, the cost calculations will not have much meaning until a large number of these new-generation nuclear plants are in operation.

If Diesendorf and Martin concentrate on cost calculations for ''commercially available, medium-sized, wind-driven generators'' for Lord Howe or Rottnest Islands or similar isolated locations they will render the Australian community some service. I think we can leave the costing of base load 1,000 megawatt power plants in highly industrialised countries in the hands of indigenous experts.

The fact that nuclear power is by far the most rapidly growing form of energy on a global basis is not because of an international conspiracy by vested interests, but due to informed, clear-thinking realism.

Those readers of The Australian Financial Review who wish to have access to facts on this topic might do well to consult the recently published book, The Economics of Nuclear Energy, edited by Brookes and Motamen and published by Chapman and Hall.
LESLIE KEMENY, Senior Lecturer in Nuclear Engineering University of NSW, Sydney.
Australian Financial Review
Chipp should do homework

Sir, if the Australian Democrats' opposition to uranium mining is based on arguments such as the ones presented in Senator Chipp's letter (AFR, May 17) then I must sadly conclude that some politicians prefer rhetoric to rational discourse.

The senator, as many other modern Luddites, is now saying that not only nuclear power is bad, but all forms of centralised energy generation are also to be condemned. To him the answer is in ''soft energy strategies'' as proposed by Amory Lovins, a so-called ''distinguished academic''.

According to a group of 41 energy experts, from 18 countries and international agencies, working under the auspices of the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development, the relative capital costs per kW average output for different types of generating stations are-in relative monetary units-coal 100, nuclear 174, wind 426, waves 648, and solar 1,495 (one unit being approximately equal to $5.45 at 1981 values).

When the costs of capital investment, operation, maintenance and fuel are taken into account, the average costs of electricity per kW/h for the 11 countries included in the study show nuclear power to be 41.7 per cent cheaper than coal- fuelled stations.
If Senator Chipp would for once consider the alternative view, he could obtain the study I mentioned above. It retails for only $8.

Senator Chipp prefers to mislead us by restating once again that cancellation of electrical facilities in the US is the consequence of market forces. It must be understood that in that country electrical power generating capacity is largely in excess of demand. The US, with the largest per capita consumption of energy in the world, is one of the few countries where small increases in energy efficiency will result in considerable savings of their often inefficient use of power.
This is not the case for most of the rest of mankind, and certainly offers no hopes to the have-nots of our unfortunate world.

To say that nuclear power is expanding not because of recent policy decisions but because of overruns and inefficiences is to ignore that in the last six months of 1983, the construction of seven new reactors has been announced ( reports in Time, February 13, 1984, and AFR, April 10, 1984). It is also to ignore that in its most recent annual report the World Bank recommends the investment of $53.2 billion in nuclear energy for developing countries in the period from 1984 to 1995. I would respectfully suggest the senator must do his homework better.

In typical fashion, Senator Chipp calls his opponents one-track minded. It seems then that his qualification must also apply to the OECD, the World Bank, the Commission of the European Countries, the International Energy Agency, and dozens more of the professional organisations that happen to disagree with the vague and emotional arguments of the Leader of the Democrats.

Consider the following: 72.5 per cent of the global consumption of 134.9 billion barrels of oil equivalent in 1980 was supplied from oil and gas, 45.5 per cent from oil (World Bank, World Development Report 1983).

According to the best available estimates, oil and gas production supply will fall behind demand some time in the next 15 years, and therefore is to be expected that recent oil price fluctuations will be short-lived and to be followed by supply-inelastic prices. (A.R. Flower, Sc. Am. March 1978). Moreover , replacement of oil and gas by coal may demand the annual production of 15 billion tonnes of coal equivalent in the year 2000, seven and a half times the current production, clearly an unattainable goal even in the most optimistic scenario.

The poorer three-fourths of the world population, with a per capita GDP one fourth of the world average, currently consume only, one-fifth of all the fuel produced in the world, demonstrably well below optimum energy sufficiency. (Word Bank, ibid.) To bring them to energy sufficiency with fossil fuels will result in the exhaustion of this finite source of energy in the first half of the next century.

How is the senator proposing to solve this most pressing crisis? Perhaps the answer is in ''soft technologies'' such as wood burning in the caves! Simply stated, senator, real energy options are but a few; Lovins ''soft energy'' is nothing but pie in the sky.

On the safety issue, an exhaustive risk assessment for each of the major energy sources-oil, coal, natural gas and nuclear-as well as for a host of renewable resources, including wind, ocean thermal, solar space heating photovoltaics and methanol, arrived at the conclusion that renewable sources of energy posed risks as great, and often greater than, conventional energy sources. Perhaps more importantly is the observation that nuclear energy is less risky overall (by about a factor of 10) than almost any other energy source, conventional or otherwise (H. Inhaber, ''Energy Risk Assessment'', Gordon and Breach, NY, 1982).

Finally, Senator Chipp calls Amory Lovins a distinguished academic and claims that ''many US utilities are hiring him to get them out of nuclear power''. Being a latter-day Thomas, I seriously doubt these assertions and call on Senator Chipp to substantiate them.
C. SORENTINO, East Ryde, NSW

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is totally opposed to this Bill for reasons which I think are obvious.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Mr Acting Deputy President, thank you for the call. I do point out that I close the debate and I would not wish to preclude any other senator from speaking.
—Yes, I recognise that Senator Chipp , but no one else has risen to speak. (Quorum formed)

—Although every honourable senator thinks that the private member' s Bill he introduces is the most important Bill ever to be debated by the Senate , I would have thought that a Bill brought in by me which is designed totally to preclude any opportunity Australia has of ever becoming a nuclear power, of ever building its own nuclear bomb, would have attracted more than 45 minutes debate in this place and would have brought more than five senators to their feet. I believe it is an absolute scandal, an absolute disgrace and an absolute condemnation of the major political parties in this country that a matter upon which the fate and safety of every Australian might well depend attracts only five speakers.
—I take a point of order. Many people who wanted to speak on this matter were asked not to do so by the Whips because they want to get to a vote. I believe that Senator Chipp knows that.
—There is no point of order.
—Can I speak to the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President?
—Senator Chipp, there is no point of order. The honourable senator has the call and he can speak to the motion.

—Thank you. I would have liked the opportunity of replying to the point of order raised by Senator Townley. Two and a half hours, beginning at a quarter to four, have been allotted for debate on General Business matters. It is now 4.30 p.m. There are still almost two hours left to debate this legislation if members of the Senate want to. The only other matter listed for debate is an important matter that has been raised by Senator MacGibbon. However , there would have been plenty of time to deal with that.

SPEECH.PARA: I regard it as a tragedy that there seems to be so little interest in the subject before the Senate at the moment. What does the Customs (Prohibition of Importation of Nuclear Hardware) Bill 1984 seek to do? Passage of this Bill would have prevented the establishment of a nuclear industry in Australia. It would have put paid for all time to any question of Australia building a nuclear bomb.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or nuclear research.

—'Or nuclear research' says Senator Sir John Carrick. Senator Walsh and Senator Jessop have made something of this point. Indeed, it would seem that the information that Senator Jessop provided was almost identical with that provided in the speech made by Senator Walsh. No doubt the information he got came from either Senator Walsh's office or the Department of Resources and Energy and, of course, there is nothing wrong with that. I want to answer the interjection of Senator Sir John Carrick and the statements of Senator Walsh and Senator Jessop about the exclusions that I have put in my Bill. Nuclear hardware could still be imported for the manufacture of industrial isotopes and medical isotopes. They said that the Bill would totally end any possibilities for research for industrial or other purposes. In answer I refer them to clause 6(2) (b), which they must have read. Sub-clause (2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: A permission to import nuclear hardware-

(b) shall not be granted to the Australian Atomic Energy Agency unless the Minister is satisfied that the nuclear hardware is essential for the purpose of enabling the Australian Atomic Energy Agency to maintain its capacity to produce isotopes for medical or industrial use;

I would submit that clause 6(2)(b) would have been ample to enable a Minister to use his discretion in that regard. So I do not regard as serious the allegations that this Bill would finish any form of nuclear research for the purposes mentioned by Senator Walsh, Senator Jessop and Senator Sir John Carrick.

This Bill would have allowed Australians to rest easy. Australia could not have built a nuclear bomb and it could not have added further to the proliferation of nuclear weapons in this region. I find it incredible that the Government now in power talks about a nuclear free zone and denounces French nuclear tests in the Pacific yet still allows Australia to have the capacity to build a nuclear bomb when by agreeing to this Bill it could have denied future governments or, for that matter, anybody, the opportunity of doing just that.

I, along with a great number of other Australians, was terrified when I read some months ago the leaked strategic basis paper from the Defence Department as disclosed by the National Times. Nobody who read those leaked papers could conclude anything else but that the generals and the boffins over at Russell Hill want Australia to adopt a nuclear option. Is there anybody in this chamber who does not believe that the Defence Department-the generals, the admirals and the air vice-marshals-want Australia to build a nuclear bomb? There is no doubt about it. Those papers clearly indicate that. I will have something more to say about this matter when the Slatyer report is debated. But did we have a total denial from the Government on that question? We do have a statement from the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) in response to this issue. Honourable senators will remember that Senator Gareth Evans, representing the Minister for Defence in this chamber, said that the Government had accepted that statement in principle. The Minister said:

The Government's commitment to support of the non-proliferation regime is absolute. This means that, as part of doing what it can to promote universal acceptance of the Non-Proliferation Treaty, the conclusion of a Comprehensive Test Ban and a South Pacific Nuclear Weapon Free Zone, and working for international agreement on a wide range of other measures in the arms control and disarmament arena, the Government has renounced any interest of its own in developing or otherwise acquiring nuclear weapons. It regards that renunciation as binding and permanent.

They sound like reasonable sorts of words for a government that has determined against building a nuclear bomb in Australia. After having said those words, what is this Government going to do? What is every member of the Australian Labor Party in this chamber going to do when this legislation goes to a vote within five minutes time? They are going to vote against the Bill that would nail that conclusion to its policy. They are going to vote against a Bill that would allow them to go out of this place and say: 'I put my democratic vote to a Bill that will prevent any government building a nuclear bomb in Australia'. Yet they are not going to do that.

I heard some interjections from honourable senators on my right when I made a reference to those people at Russell Hill still wanting the nuclear option. Senator Jessop was gracious enough to answer an interjection I made during his speech. But during that speech Senator MacGibbon clearly said: 'I would advocate building a nuclear bomb in Australia if our neighbours acquired one'. I am not saying that Senator Jessop has this mentality because he made his position clear . But this is clearly the position adopted by some people in this place. That is why I introduced this Bill. I introduced it for those sabre-rattlers, those people who believe that nuclear proliferation is the only answer to detente or the only way in which--

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not really believe that Australians are sabre-rattlers, do you, Senator?

—I said there are some people in this place who are sabre-rattlers . There are people who would advocate the building of a nuclear bomb or advocate our having the wherewithal to build a nuclear bomb if our neighbours acquire one . There are people in this place who believe that. All I am saying is that the passage of the Bill would prevent the possibility of Australia building a nuclear bomb if our neighbours acquire one.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation in the world now is desperate. Arthur Koestler, one of the greatest minds of our time, said in one of his last books that, because of man's incapacity to gear his emotional responses to technological explosions, man's self-induced extinction from this planet is now approaching a statistical certainty. Is that scare-monger tactics or is it the truth? Let us examine that. As I stand here today, there are 50,000 nuclear bombs in existence. Something like 36,000 of those bombs are pointing at human beings. There are some nuclear bombs pointing at Australians. That admission was made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden).

Let us look at the arsenal of 50,000 nuclear bombs now in existence. The average bomb has 42 times the destructive power of the bombs that were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. My finite mind finds difficulty in comprehending that kind of destruction. The bomb dropped on Nagasaki killed about 200,000 human beings in a most devastating way. Many of them were not killed instantly but died over six-day, six-month and six-year periods. Those 50,000 bombs would kill on average 42 times 200,000. Many of them would die in a way that would make them envy the dead. I am talking about the average bomb, not the biggest bomb. The 50 megatonne bomb is certainly beyond my power to comprehend. Its destructive power is greater than the sum total of all the explosives let off in the six years of the Second World War. It would virtually fit under the desk which stands in front of you, Mr Acting Deputy Speaker.

This is the kind of destructive power humankind has now created in this world. We now have the capacity to destroy all life on this planet within a reasonably short time, yet we continue to mine, mill and sell our uranium for profit. We persist with the myth that we are exporting our uranium to get a few dollars. That is incidental. We are not doing it because of the dollars we get for it; we are doing it because it allows us to use more leverage in international affairs to make nuclear bombs safe. Has that policy succeeded to this point? Has the production of nuclear bombs diminished since we began exporting our uranium? That argument has never been substantiated. It is like saying that if we want to prevent murders being committed in this country we have to join Murder Incorporated. I have never heard such an absurd, illogical argument. Let those who put that argument be honest and say that we are exporting our uranium for money. That is the only reason why we are exporting our uranium. If it is not for the money we are getting from exports, it is for the money that people earn from jobs. I am not saying that it is not important for people to have jobs. Of course it is. I am not saying that the people who will be disadvantaged by the cancellation of our contracts for uranium should suffer. Any person who lost his job through the banning of the exporting of uranium should not suffer at all. Those persons should be compensated from the taxes paid by the rest of the Australians who have not been so disadvantaged. If somebody said to me that that would result in a slightly lower standard of living for most Australians I would say 'So be it'; I would rather accept half the standard of living that I have now and at least have off my conscience the fact that, by my actions in exporting uranium, I am endangering the world and putting all people, particularly children, under a threat which they do not deserve. Let those who talk about nuclear bombs tell me about one nuclear bomb that has not been manufactured from uranium. Yet we continue to export it at the most scandalous and hideous rate.

If the Labor Party objects to my Bill because, as Senator Tate and Senator Walsh indicated, it would be unduly restrictive of the use of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, let it make a simple amendment to it. It has been available for consideration for several weeks. If the Government feels that technically it would have been too limiting, it has the resources of its departments, and of the parliamentary counsel to make some simple amendments to my Bill to make it such that it would not be unduly restrictive. It has not done that. Clearly, this Labor Government is embracing the nuclear industry with a vigour and with a passion that would rival Malcolm Fraser's Government and other Liberal governments. It is a shame to be a part of a parliament in which one can observe that happening. The Australian Labor Party should remember that hundreds of thousands of Australians voted for it at the last election because they genuinely believed that the Labor Party wanted to defuse the nuclear situation. They believed the words and the unequivocal commitment of the Labor Party to phase out uranium mining. They believed what was said about a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific. Those sorts of statements attracted hundreds of thousands of people who had never voted for Labor in their lives. They felt their children were imperilled and voted for Labor because of that. I say after consideration and not in a moment of political passion that the Labor Party has betrayed those people who cast their votes because they thought that, by voting for the Labor Party, they would find some safety.

If the Government cannot amend my Bill because of some technical difficulty, why does it not produce its own Bill? Why does it not close off the nuclear option? Clearly, this Government is keeping its nuclear options open. There can be no other interpretation of the Government's action today in unanimously opposing this Bill. The only purpose of the Bill is to prevent Australia, under any circumstances, building a nuclear bomb without disadvantaging the way in which medical and industrial isotopes can be manufactured. I sometimes despair of the justifications for the nuclear industry.

Senator Jessop, whom I admire in many respects, spoke about alternative uses. Surely alternative uses are the only safe and long term solution to the energy problems of England, Europe, Australia and the rest of the world. In quoting my letter to the Australian, Senator Jessop spoke about the United Kingdom experience. He said that research showed that alternative energy from wood, coal , wind, solar and tidal energy and all other alternatives would supply only 15 per cent of the needs of industry in the United Kingdom by the turn of the century. I interjected by saying: 'What is your source?' He was kind enough and gracious enough to answer my interjection by saying: 'The Uranium Information Centre'. That would be like my asking the Tobacco Institute of Australia Ltd for its view on whether tobacco smoking causes lung cancer. It is ludicrous.

I have two private member's Bills before the Senate. One, the Customs ( Prohibition of Exportation of Nuclear Materials) Bill 1984, is designed to ban totally the export of uranium. The Bill before us is designed to ban the importation of nuclear hardware, except for medical and industrial use. I have given up hope, because of the direction that the Australian Labor Party has taken, of its voting for the first mentioned Bill. That is why I did not bring it forward today at this opportunity to deal with private business. Clearly, the Government has taken a turn to mine the biggest uranium mine in the world at Roxby Downs. I brought forward this Bill hoping, perhaps naively, that the Government might honour its election promise by voting for it. I am about to give Government members the opportunity to stand up and be counted by calling for a division to decide whether this Bill shall pass the second reading stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to answer the charge the Senator Chipp made that I had said that I was in favour of nuclear weapons. I did not say that. I asked the question, by way of interjection: What would the position be if some or all of our neighbours had nuclear weapons? Later I said that we might find that a large number of Australians would demand that their parliamentary representatives do something about it.
