TALK.START.PARA: —(Minister for Resources and Energy) (6.15)-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1984

The main purpose of this Bill is to adjust grants to government and non- government schools in the States and Northern Territory for cost increases, in line with the Government's very important decision to re-introduce retrospective cost supplementation arrangements for Schools Commission programs. These arrangements represent a considerable step forward for school systems and authorities and mean that they are now able to plan ahead in the confidence that grants will be maintained in real terms. This will involve a further appropriation of $9.7m. This Bill also includes a number of minor amendments including clarifying some aspects of building and equipment grants for schools serving predominantly Aboriginal communities.

In the second reading debate on the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill 1983, I undertook to establish an independent appeals tribunal to consider appeals by non-government schools against their classification for recurrent funding purposes. I have had the matter under consideration and I have asked the Schools Commission to consult with non-government school authorities and organisations on the form of a suitable appeals mechanism before the necessary legislation is introduced in the Budget Session. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1984

The primary purposes of this Bill is to adjust grants to universities, colleges of advanced education and technical and further education institutions for cost increases, in line with the Government's decision to re-introduce retrospective cost supplementation arrangements for Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission Programs. Under these arrangements, all wage and salary increases during the program year will be met, while increases in non-salary and capital costs will continue to be met up to the beginning of each program year. These arrangements make an important contribution to rational and stable planning by tertiary institutions.
The total amount of supplementation to be provided under this Bill is $62.2m.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1984

The primary purpose of this Bill is to supplement for cost increases the grants available to government and non-government education authorities in the States and the Northern Territory to conduct projects and programs under the new Participation and Equity Program which the Government introduced this year. This adjustment is in accord with the government's undertaking to provide retrospective cost supplementation for this program. The adjustments are consistent with those being made to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) and States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bills which are also before the Senate today. This supplementation will involve a further appropriation of $1.074m for each of the years 1984, 1985 and 1986.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian National University Act 1946 in order to remove provisions inserted in the Act in 1979 and 1981 which restrict the activities of student organisations in the University. In addition to this primary purpose, the Bill provides for a number of minor amendments to the Act most of which have been requested by the University.

The amendments made to the Australian National University Act in 1979 and 1981 by the Fraser Government were directed at restricting the ways in which fees levied on students for the provision of amenities and services could be used. An objective was to prevent these fees being used for so called 'socio-political' purposes, including affiliation by a student association with a national association of students.

These restrictions involve an unwarranted intrusion into the internal affairs of the University. Students should be free to make decisions about how they run their organisations subject to their accountability to the governing body of the University. A wide range of student activities should be a normal feature of campus life. It is for the Council of the Australian National University to decide, not the Government, what are appropriate uses for funds levied to provide amenities and services. To impose restrictions of this nature represents an unacceptable limitation on the proper autonomy of the Council as the governing body of the University.

It is the Government's intention to repeal the restrictions brought into the Act in 1979 and 1981 so that the Act in the area of funding amenities and services for students will return to the situation existing prior to the 1979 amendments. The Council of the University has been consulted and has indicated that it welcomes the action the Government is taking. It will again be the responsibility of the Council to supervise the use of these funds as an aspect of its general responsibility for the governance of the University.

The Bill also provides for a number of minor amendments to the ANU Act. The Bill removes from the Act the provision for an annual appropriation of $650,000 for the University. This provision goes back to the establishment of the University in 1946 but has been overtaken by time. As the annual appropriation for the University for running expenses is now of the order of $121m, it is sensible to remove this anachronism from the Act and to add this amount to the funds appropriated each year for the University.

A number of amendments requested by the University are included in the Bill. These include the removal of sex-discriminatory language from the Act, the addition of student representation to the Board of the Institute of Advanced Studies, the establishment of the position of Treasurer as an office of the University, and the up-dating of penalties for traffic offences on University land. The Bill gives the University power to make Statutes authorising the disposal of vehicles abandoned on University land after reasonable efforts have been made to trace their owners.

The opportunity is also being taken to make some formal amendments to the ANU Act and to bring this Act into line with current legislative practice in several matters. These are the provision for disclosure of interests by members of the University Council and for disqualification of a member of Council. The Bill has no implications for Commonwealth funding of the ANU. Fees for amenities and services are levied from students by the University Council at rates approved by the Council and do not involve Commonwealth expenditure.

This Bill gives effect to a principle of considerable importance in defining the respective roles of government and university governing bodies in the management of institutions. It embraces a broad concept of the nature and value of a university education. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CANBERRA COLLEGE OF ADVANCED EDUCATION AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Bill is a companion measure to the Bill to amend the Australian National University Act. It is similarly directed at removing the provisions inserted in the Canberra College of Advanced Education Act in 1979 which restrict the activities of student organisations in the college. In addition to this primary purpose, the Bill also provides for a number of minor amendments to the Act.

The Bill gives effect to the same principles in removing the restrictions imposed on the activities of student organisations in the college as does the Australian National University Amendment Bill. It is similarly based on the view that the 1979 amendments involved an unwarranted intrusion into the internal affairs of the college. The removal of these restrictions will mean that it will again be the responsibility of the College Council to supervise the use of funds levied for the provision of amenities and services as an aspect of its general responsibility for the governance of the college.

The College Council has been consulted and has indicated that it welcomes the Government's initiative in this matter. While the Government's general intention is to return to the pre-1979 statutory situation, the Bill also brings the college into line with the Australian National University in terms of categories of fees that may be covered by a determination of the College Council. This has been done in order to clarify the powers of the College Council in respect of the funding of the activities of student organisations in the college.

The Bill also provides for a number of minor amendments to the Canberra College of Advanced Education Act. These include the removal of sex-discriminatory language from the Act, enlarging the Council of the College by adding representatives of non-teaching staff and college alumni, and empowering the college to confer honourary degrees at levels approved by the Minister. In the case of the conferring of honourary degrees, the Government's intention is that the college should be able to confer honourary degrees at levels equivalent to the normal awards of the college.

The Bill provides an opportunity to make some formal amendments to the Act and to bring this Act into line with current practice. The Bill does this in respect of disclosure of interests by members of the College Council. This Bill has no implications for Commonwealth funding of the Canberra College of Advanced Education. Fees for amenities and services are levied from students by the College Council at rates approved by the Council and do not involve Commonwealth expenditure.

Like the companion Bill, this Bill gives effect to a principle pertinent to the definition of the respective roles of government and college governing bodies. It similarly derives from a broad concept of the nature and value of a college education.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The primary purpose of this Bill is to put into operation the Government's commitment to reactivate the former Curriculum Development Centre within the administrative structure of the Commonwealth Schools Commission. By this means the Commonwealth will have the capacity to provide schools and school systems with curriculum and educational materials, information and expertise. The legislation will also strengthen the integral relationship between curriculum issues, research priorities and the funding and program responsibilities of the Commonwealth Schools Commission.

To achieve its primary purpose the Bill repeals the Curriculum Centre Act 1975 and in doing so abolishes the existing Curriculum Development Centre as a statutory authority. The assets and liabilities of the existing Centre are to be vested in the Commonwealth and will be administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission.

The legislation will establish a new Curriculum Development Council, reporting to the Minister, which will work in close consultation with the Commonwealth Schools Commission. The Chairman of the Commission will have permanent head powers in relation to staff appointed under the Public Service Act 1922 to assist both the Commission and the new Curriculum Development Council.

In addition to the primary purpose of the Bill, the legislation also updates general provisions in the Commonwealth Schools Commission Act 1973 to take account of current legislative practices. The legislation also provides authority for the Commission to inquire into, and to furnish information and advice to the Minister with respect to, matters affecting the education of handicapped children who have not attained school age.

In accordance with the Government's pre-election education policy this Bill will reverse the decision taken by the Fraser Government to abolish Australia's national curriculum body. The earlier decision, arising from a recommendation of the Committee for the Review of Commonwealth Functions-the Lynch Committee-was made despite considerable public debate and a flood of objections from all quarters of the educational community, including the national parent and teacher organisations. It was a pointless decision given the significant achievements of the Curriculum Development Centre in its all too short history. It was a decision that could not have been made on the basis of any rational educational argument and a decision made all the more remarkable given that the then Minister for Education had only six weeks previously officially opened the Centre's premises with a speech praising at considerable length the Centre's achievements. That decision reflected the Fraser Government's lack of real concern for the education of our children. In contrast, the Hawke Government is committed to an educational program that will ensure that the greater majority of children in our schools are given a worthwhile and rewarding education. Central to such a goal will be the re-establishment of the Commonwealth's national curriculum role as proposed in this Bill.

One of the main outcomes to be expected from the proposed new arrangements will be a commitment to forge a closer relationship between national curriculum development and the program activities of the Commonwealth Schools Commission. This link will be instrumental in enabling the Commission to implement fully the Government's national educational priorities, in particular, to promote curriculum initiatives in such areas as Aboriginal education, the education of girls, computer education, secondary education, curriculum renewal and those programs concerned with Australia's multicultural character.

The close links to be forged between the Curriculum Development Council and the Commonwealth Schools Commission will strengthen the capacity of the Commission to bring about long term changes in Australian education. In the immediate future this increased capacity will be evident in the curriculum inputs that will be made to the announced participation and equity, and computer education programs.

The cost of reactivating the Curriculum Development Centre is expected to be between $2.5m and $3m a year, less expected revenue from sales of curriculum publications of $500,000 a year. The transfer of curriculum activities presently conducted by the Department of Education and Youth Affairs to the Curriculum Development Council will involve savings in the order of $1.5m a year which will be an offset against the costs of reactivating the Curriculum Development Centre .

The Government's participation and equity program is a cornerstone of our strategies for educational improvement and through this program it will be possible to break down the persisting patterns of disadvantage, those patterns which have made educational outcomes dependent to an unacceptable extent on the socio-economic background of the student or the student's sex, ethnic background and geographical location. The immediate emphasis of the program will be to increase the participation of young people in post-compulsory schooling, particularly Aboriginal people, working class youth, some migrant communities, rural youth and the handicapped. However, in the longer term the Government will be seeking to make education a more challenging and rewarding experience for all children.

The Government's computer education program recognises the need for all students to have an understanding of the uses of new technology and of the impact these new technologies will have on the student's social, environmental, industrial and working life. From the teachers' point of view, there will need to be planning for, and guidance in, the ways in which the computer and related technologies are to be introduced into the curriculum and into the professional development programs of both the practising teacher and the teacher trainee. The promotion of these needs, including the professional development needs of parents and community members, will be a major responsibility of the new Curriculum Development Council.

Achieving these objectives will require the full co-operation of all groups with an interest in education. It will not be an easy task and it is not one that can be left to individual schools or systems. Co-operation, co-ordination and facilitation will be necessary if the initiatives are to have a broad system impact. Central to the process will be the need to give close attention to the school curriculum, in particular, to the curriculum content, structure and organisation. In this demanding task there is a clear need for a national initiative and this is being provided for in the provisions of this Bill.

Among the initiatives that will need pursuing on the wider national front will be such issues as credentialling and assessment procedures, the analysis of curricula, the consideration of alternative organisational and structural patterns, the retraining of teachers, changes in teacher attitudes, the design and development of new courses, and, very importantly, the improvement of school -community relations and community attitudes towards both education and the outcomes of education.

The Australian Labor Party and Labor governments have traditionally been concerned with justice and equity. We have a commitment to creating a more equal society where each person can achieve his or her full potential. In education this means we are committed to assist schools to give a positive and effective education to all children, and to make substantial progress towards the more equal distribution of other outcomes of education such as access to paid employment and higher education. We believe there is an urgent need to encourage all children to obtain a full twelve years of education and thereby to increase participation in tertiary education and in the country's capacity to adapt to, and make significant contributions to, technological change. At the present time too many of our children are leaving school without completing an adequate level of education and without developing those skills that will enhance their opportunities for satisfying employment. It is also true that of those children who are leaving early a disproportionate number are coming from working class and disadvantaged groups.

In response to this situation the Hawke Labor Government has a long term goal to ensure that most young people complete a full secondary education, either in a school or in a technical and further education institution, or in some combination of work and education. Achieving this goal will require far reaching initiatives paramount among which will be the curriculum reforms I have already mentioned.

My own interest in the education of girls and of Aboriginals is well known and the reactivation of the former Curriculum Development Centre will be a vital element in the Government's policies in these areas. It is only recently that there had been a widespread recognition that schooling was not preparing girls for the economic and social realities of adult life. We do not yet have a comprehensive history of schooling for girls in Australia and that is significant in itself. We do know that over the greater part of our history there have been major differentiations between the schooling offered to girls and boys, except for that minority of girls who followed an academic path traditionally designed for privileged males. In Aboriginal education the situation is no better. It is only recently that Aboriginal history and culture has been considered a legitimate study in our schools. Virtually all of us here were treated to the history of the world and of Austrlaia from a British perspective. This Bill will enable the Government to take positive steps to set about redressing these imbalances.

In the same way that Aboriginals and girls have been limited in the benefits that they may derive from education and in the contributions they may make to the development of our country so too have several other groups including other ethnic groups and the handicapped. The multicultural nature of Australian society and the rights of all persons are still not adequately understood nor reflected in current educational practices.

The Labor Government acknowledges the diversity of the contributing cultures in Australia and it will be expected the new Curriculum Development Council to contribute to the development and dissemination of curricula that acknowledges this diversity and provides a perspective of Australia as a nation in the Asian- Pacific region. The challenge ahead of us is to turn schools, and the formal education system, into places and experiences which young people will really enjoy and find value in. We need to re-affirm the traditional and positive concern of schooling with the development of the individual, and to place less stress on the function of school as a social sorting system. It is a debasement of the purposes of education to use schools as a weeding out device. They should not be places where for many students their main experience is one of frustration and inadequacy.

This is not to downplay academic achievement and high educational standards and indeed the Government fully recognises the need to improve the education and preparation of those who are moving into higher levels of education. However, this must not be done at the expense of the many students for whom schooling is the route to gainful employment and a satisfying adult life. The objective must be to provide a satisfying and demanding education for all students. The Hawke Government believes that this objective can be achieved if the Commonwealth supports school curriculum and practice in a positive and direct way. Such support should build upon the intellectual and social resources of students and their school communities and give to students the confidence and understanding necessary to shape individually and collectively the circumstances of their own lives.

In the curriculum context the emphasis will be on the Commonwealth, through the Curriculum Development Council, taking a positive stance in co-ordinating, facilitating and in broad terms supporting the development of curriculum strategies in association with existing curriculum groups throughout the country . The aim will be to achieve increased co-operation and understanding between the Commonwealth and the States, to extend the involvement of teachers and parents in the curriculum process, and to expand co-operation between all sectors of the educational fabric.

Through such endeavours the Government is confident that all Australian children whatever their economic, social, ethnic or geographical background will be able to enjoy as near as practicable an equal and worthwhile educational opportunity. In proposing that the Commonwealth play a positive role in this process the Government fully recognises that State governments have the prime responsibility for education. However, the Government believes it is possible, and indeed highly desirable, for the Commonwealth to participate and for the Curriculum Development Council to work in partnership with the States in building on the work now being done in the States and to seek ways of co- operatively developing new approaches to traditional subject matter as well as new subjects, new organisational and structural patterns, and forms of teaching and learning that will make school a more interesting and constructive experience for all students.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to a matter raised during the consideration of the estimates for the Department of Communications when Senator Sir John Carrick asked a number of questions relating to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Answers to those questions have been delivered to the honourable senator's office and I seek leave to have those answers incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Question: What are the entertainment and travelling expenses of the Chairman and Board of the ABC in 1983-84? Are these expenses substantially larger than the previous Chairman and Board of ABC?
Answer: The following table shows entertainment and travelling expenses for the Chairman and Board of the ABC to date for 1983-84 with comparable figures for the Commissioners in 1982-83
1 July 1982- 1 July 1983- Board/Commission
$ $ Entertainment expenses 9,431 8,459 Travelling expenses 74,904 74,062
Question: Have notices of abolition of positions gone out to senior officers recently?
Answer: Yes.
Question: Did these apply to the Legal Section?
Answer: Yes. Four professional legal positions were abolished and the affected staff were notified.
Question: Is there any intention to restructure the Legal Section and if so how ?

Answer: Yes. The Board of the ABC has created senior Legal positions in both Radio and Television Divisions and a further Legal position in the Directorate of Engineering and Property. The structure below the senior legal positions in each media will be determined by an Establishment and Systems review which is expected to make recommendations to the Board at its August meeting.
Question: Could you confirm that existing legislation does not provide for a staff member on the Board and that in fact no staff representative is on the Board.
Would you provide advice on
whether a staff representative sits on the ABC Board meetings?
is there any advisory committee mechanism whereby staff views are conveyed to the Board.

The existing legislation does not provide for a staff member on the ABC Board. However the Government made a commitment to the Senate during passage of the ABC Bill in the 1983 Autumn sittings to consider legislative provisions for a staff elected Director. The Department of Communications is currently preparing proposals for amendments of the ABC Act to provide for a staff elected Director. These proposals are expected to be considered by the Government shortly.

In late 1983 the Government arranged for an election to be conducted amongst ABC staff by the Australian Electoral Office for a person to be recommended for appointment as a Director. Mr Tom Molomby was elected and was subsequently appointed by the Governor-General as a Director of the Board of the Corporation for a period of two years from 15 December 1983.
To the extent that Mr Molomby, a staff member, was elected by the staff and subsequently appointed to the Board, he is the staff representative on the Board .

Mr Molomby, being a non-executive Director appointed pursuant to Section 12 of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 attends the Board meetings as a Director. No other staff representative sits in on Board meetings.

There is no single advisory committee mechanism whereby staff views are conveyed to the Board. However, three members of the Board of management are elected by the staff. Further, major decisions affecting staff are made after consultation with the relevant industrial organisations in the ABC.
Department of Health
Proposed expenditure, $30,955,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —In our previous consideration of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1983-84 Senator Walters asked about three market surveys but I was unable to answer her in detail. One survey was conducted on section 17 disputes with the doctors. That survey is presently a working document of the Government and is being actively used in formulating Government policies and priorities. The other two surveys are not yet completed and have not been presented to the Minister. They will be used to formulate Government policy and priorities in these areas. The Government will release the results of the surveys when they are no longer being used in the preparation of policy.

—I thank the Minister. The other question which as far as I know has not been answered by the Department of Health appears at page 35 of the Hansard record of the hearings of Estimates Committee B, when I asked the same question as I asked during consideration of the estimates for the Department of Social Security. The question is: Can the Minister tell me how much money is budgeted to be spent on consultants this year? I do not believe that was answered by the Department.
—The answer is $305 ,000.
—I thank the Minister. He may have to get this for me or he may have it now, but I would like the names of the consultants.
—I can describe the consultancies but I cannot at this moment give Senator Walters the exact names. I think Senator Walters has the descriptions of the consultancies.
—I did get the descriptions but I did not get the names. I did not actually ask for them; I thought it was implicit in the question.
—I have the descriptions but not the names. I will certainly obtain the names for the honourable senator.

—I thank the Minister. There are several questions which I have been told only the Minister can answer. First of all, has there been a reassessment of the original estimate of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of nine out of 10 people in Australia being better off under Medicare?

—I do not have the exact figure here. All I can say is that we are all better off for having a universal health insurance scheme. For instance, if even Senator Walters or I were to suffer a catastrophic accident or illness which could only be treated in a public hospital we would be better off. I assume she means financially better off. I will ask the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) to make an attempt to get those figures.

—I hope the Minister is taking this seriously because it is a serious question. I would like to know what percentage of Australians are better off financially under the new scheme, bearing in mind the 15 per cent that is paid out to cover the schedule fee. As the Minister would know, that would be based on an average of the number of calls for which a patient would have to pay.

—I assure the honourable senator I take that question very seriously. But in some ways being better off is in the eye of the beholder. For instance, I would consider myself better off under Medicare if I suddenly, catastrophically, had an accident which put me in hospital for a year, or required some sort of procedure which was beyond my ordinary financial capacities to pay and which left me in a state where I was unable even to continue the onerous task of being a senator in this place. I would be reassured that as a result of the introduction of a universal health insurance scheme my capacity to be treated in public hospitals with good facilities would not be restricted by my capacity to pay. I take that very seriously and I think it is a very serious argument for the introduction of a universal insurance scheme. I understand that Senator Walters is taking a much narrower approach than that. She wants to know by how much a week various individuals are better or worse off under Medicare. I will certainly seek to get that information for her.

—I thank the Minister. As he would be well aware, we could enter into a debate on whether the previous system also arranged for the catastrophic situation to which he referred, but I do not believe that this is the correct time or place to do that.
—Hear, hear!

—If the interjections are to be so ridiculous, perhaps we ought to enter into that debate. I have a quarter of an hour in which to speak, so it depends how the Government is prepared to take the statements I am making. If it would prefer me to enter into that debate, by all means I will. I ask the Minister whether legal opinion has been sought by the Department on the legality or otherwise of Medicare keeping the patient's receipt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters asked during the Estimates Committee hearing whether a legal opinion had been obtained on the validity of holding doctors' receipts against the patient's wishes. I thought she would have received an answer, but as it appears she has not I will provide the answer now: The policy of not returning doctors' receipts as a matter of course was adopted by the Health Insurance Commission in the light of the health insurance industry's experience with fraudulent practices prior to the introduction of Medicare. These documents provide the only reliable evidence to support the payment of benefits and their automatic return would limit the Commission's ability to complete effective audit of these payments.

SPEECH.PARA: This policy is consistent with the views of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts on medical fraud and overservicing. It also seeks to avoid criticisms such as those made by the Auditor-General in his report of May 1983 on the unacceptability of fund records as support for the payment of Commonwealth medical benefits.

The Commission is prepared to issue a statement of benefit for cash claims, but only on request. Also, a person will be able to obtain an annual statement on request, of benefits paid. These facilities will assist claimants in the preparation of their taxation returns. This is the most common reason advanced by persons seeking return of the accounts and receipts. However, the Commission recognises that some people will need their documents for other reasons. In these cases provision has been made for the accounts to be returned after the claim has been processed for payment by cheque. Legal advice available to the Commission indicates that, subject to this provision, there is no legal impediment to the Commission's retaining account documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek clarification of that answer. If I take my receipt in to claim a benefit and ask to have it back, will it definitely be returned to me?

—According to the answer I have, it will be returned after it has been used to process the account . If I can make a correction to a previous answer-we have some mathematical problems here-the appropriation for consultants is $859,000, not $305,000, as I previously indicated.

—I raise a matter of mechanics which has been raised with me several times, and this may be an appropriate opportunity to get an answer. Juveniles living away from home are generally requested by the places at which they stay or board to produce Medicare cards of their own. However, as they are juveniles they do not pay their own bills and the bills are sent to their parents, who pay them. However, the parents are unable to claim the refunds because the cards are not in their names. This is a ridiculous situation . Can the mechanics be tidied up?

—Quite frankly, my advisers do not understand the question. The card for a juvenile is the same family card. It has the same number, I believe. It can certainly be claimed upon . I will seek further information, but I am a little surprised at that question because I understand that people who are away at boarding school or are at university, for instance, even though dependants, have their own cards which are part of the family card.
—That is not the case. I will put it to the Minister in writing later on.
—We will look at it then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask the Minister some questions regarding medifraud. In the Estimates Committee hearings, as the Minister will remember, I asked for the Department's opinion regarding Professor McNeil's criticisms of the Department's methodology. I have received an answer, and perhaps if I read it it will explain my concern. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee sought the Department's view on certain criticisms made by Professor D. McNeil of Macquarie University. The criticisms were directed at the Department's methodology used to estimate the level of fraud and overservicing.

Professor McNeil's criticisms were published in the Medical Journal of Australia on 17 March 1984. So far as we are aware, he had not previously contacted the Department on the basis of the estimates.
This next part is particularly important:

The Department has consistently made clear that the methodology adopted to construct the estimate does not provide any evaluation of the precision of the estimate but, rather, provides quantitative estimates of the general magnitude of medical benefits fraud and overservicing.
That very clearly says to me that it is a rather loose estimate. It is a general estimate. Is my interpretation of that correct?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. It is perfectly clear to me. The Department does not pretend to any precision in the estimate. It is not suggesting that it is an exact estimate. It gives an estimate of the general magnitude of medical fraud and overservicing. I agree that the answer contains a bit of jargon and convoluted language, but that is what it means, and that is what it means to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted that verified because of the Minister's letter to the Medical Journal of Australia of 21 January 1984. Referring to the statement he had made to the House on 15 November, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the statement I outlined the methodology for calculation of the estimate for the 1981-82 financial year, and pointed out that this is similar to, but more rigorous than, that used to deduce the estimate of $100 million for 1980-81.
The estimated fraud and overservicing for 1981-82 is $120 million . . . the procedures followed would give a figure of the correct magnitude.

I find it very difficult to marry those two statements. With respect to the procedures followed the Minister said that the Australian Medical Association had agreed that there was an estimate of $100m, after the Department had taken the AMA and its accountants through the procedures. He said the AMA had agreed that that figure could not be proved or refuted until further investigations into individual cases had been conducted, but that the procedures followed would give a figure of the correct magnitude. The Department is telling us that the figure is a very general estimate. The Minister is telling us that it is far more rigorous than that undertaken in the previous year, which established, as far as he was concerned, a $100m estimate of fraud. He said that the following year, when it was established that it was $120m, it was far more rigorous and that he was satisfied that it was pretty accurate. Can the Minister tell me who is correct-the Minister or the Department?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have trouble coping with Senator Walters's question. We are talking about an estimate, a best estimate, which gives a general magnitude of the degree of medical fraud. I understood the honourable senator to say that there was some considerable difference between $100m and $120m.
—I will put it again.

—Senator Walters had better put it again because I would have thought that those figures were consistent with both statements-'there is a general magnitude' and 'there is a correct magnitude', whichever expression one uses. Quite frankly, I believe that if the amount is $30m, $50m or $100m it is too much and we should do something about it.

—The Minister has missed the point. What I am saying is that the Department said that it is a pretty rough old guess, as I understood it; whereas the Minister said that it is pretty accurate. If the Minister can explain to me how the two statements marry I will be very grateful.

—I do not believe for one minute that the Department is saying that it is a pretty rough old guess . What it is saying is that it is an estimate which provides a quantative estimate of the general magnitude of medical frauds and overservicing. I understand that the letter from the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, said that the later methods give the correct magnitude. But we are talking about magnitude . No one in the Department or anywhere else is saying that it is $100m, $102m or $105m. We are talking about an amount in the order of $100m. Senator Walters may well disagree with that, but no one in the department is claiming that that figure has the degree of exactitude that I think she would like it to have. I make the point that if it is $100m, plus or minus $50m, to me it is too much and we have a public responsibility to do something about it.

—I agree with the Minister on that, as he would well know. The Department says that there is no precision about the figure, that it is a very general estimate, but the Minister seems to be saying that the figure indicates a correct magnitude. What the Minister is hanging his hat on is that the word 'magnitude' is used. I suppose I have to leave it at that. During the Estimates Committee hearing an officer told me that Professor McNeil had been invited to join the Department. I gathered at that time that he thought Professor McNeil had joined the Department and he was going to bring me up to date on the matter. I gather the professor has not yet answered. Can the Minister tell me whether there is any more up to date information on whether Professor McNeil will be joining the Department to examine the methodology used by the Department following his criticisms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer from the Department states:

SPEECH.PARA: Professor McNeil visited the Department on 14 May and had discussions with officers in relation to his suggestion that sampling techniques could be employed. He has since given evidence to the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts on 21 May 1984. In both discussions with the departmental officers and his evidence to the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts, Professor McNeil indicated that he accepts that there may well be practical difficulties that are too great to justify proceeding with such sample surveys, although he continues to advocate their use. Professor McNeil has also indicated that he recognised that as a detection system FODS may be reasonably effective at least as a starting point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister explain what that last sentence means? I do not understand it.

—It means that Professor McNeil has indicated to the Department and the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts that he recognises that as a detection system, FODS -the fraud and overservicing detection system-may be reasonably effective at least as a starting point.

—I have before me a figure of $725,000. I believe that figure represents the amount that has been recovered from doctors who have been charged and convicted of fraud and overservicing in this financial year. We have recovered $725,000 at a cost of $3.5m. Has the Department been able to come up with a more economical method of dealing with this minority of doctors who are ripping off the system?

—I can understand the good senator believing that the recovery of $752,382 from fraud and overservicing from 1 July to 31 March has not been considerably cost effective, but I remind her that this is only the start of a program to see whether we cannot do something about fraud and overservicing. I would have thought that the recovery of that amount of money from four doctors indicated that we are well on the track to doing that. It is a five-year program to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of this system. I think that to judge it on this one year's situation is not a very reliable method of judging it. I believe the Department is always trying to get more efficient ways of doing this. If the honourable senator is suggesting that it is not worth while chasing $752,382 from four doctors because it costs a few dollars more than that to collect it, I suggest that she think of the consequences of not seeking to do so-not attempting to deal with fraud and overservicing-and the consequences of doctors having the capacity to do that with the absolute certainty that no one will do anything about it. I think that such a situation would be fairly horrific for the Budget and for the health expenditure of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister is quite well aware of my views on fraud and overservicing. I will not be intimidated by him saying that I suggested that it is all too expensive and should not be done. I have not suggested that in any way. There is no point in his putting words into my mouth with the intention that I will not ask questions about it, because it certainly will not work with me. He should have woken up to that fact a long time ago. Both of us have been members of this Parliament for some time.
